properties.name: Load Testing GDevelop
properties.description:
Create thousands of objects to see how they impact the performance of the game.
In real games, consider staying under these limits:

Sprites:
 
Desktop < 10,000
Desktop (with physics collisions) < 1,000
Desktop (with collisions) < 500

Mobile < 5,000
Mobile (with physics collisions) < 500
Mobile (with collisions) < 250

Tiled Sprites:

Desktop < 1000
Desktop (with physics collisions) < 1000
Desktop (with collisions) < 1000

Mobile < 100

Particles: 

Desktop < 15,000
Mobile < 5,000

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: DraggablePhysics
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Drag a physics object with the mouse (or touch).
description: Enables players to click and drag on physics objects to move them.  The object retains velocity when the click is released, allowing players to fling objects across the screen.
Note:
- The default "draggable" behavior will not work on objects with the physics behavior. This extension should be used instead.
- This extension will only work on objects that have the physics behavior.
- Kinematic physics mode is incompatible with this extension. The object will be changed to dynamic mode.
The Parking Jam example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://parking-jam)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Drag a physics object with the mouse (or touch).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ColorConversion
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Expressions to convert color values between various formats (RGB, HSV, HSL, named colors), calculate luminance according to WCAG 2.0 standards, and to blend two colors.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: Expressions to convert color values between various formats (RGB, HSV, HSL, named colors), calculate luminance according to WCAG 2.0 standards, and to blend two colors.

eventsFunctions.description: Converts a hexadecimal string into a RGB string.  Example input: "0459AF".
eventsFunctions.name: HexToRgb

inlineCode: if (v.toString(16) === n.toUpperCase()) throw 'input is not hexadecimal';
n = n.replace(shorthandRegex, function (m, r, g, b) {
return r + r + g + g + b + b;
console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

eventsFunctions.description: Calculate luminance of a RGB color.  Example input: "0;128;255".

inlineCode: // Convert the color string to an array of RGB values

eventsFunctions.description: Calculate luminance of a hexadecimal color.  Example input: "0459AF".
eventsFunctions.name: HexToLuminance

inlineCode: // Convert the color string to an array of RGB values

eventsFunctions.description: Blend two RGB colors by applying a weighted mean.
eventsFunctions.name: RgbMean

inlineCode: // split do allocations, but the code a lot simpler this way.
const r = gdjs.evtTools.common.clamp(Math.round((1 - ratio) * r1 + ratio * r2), 0, 255);
const g = gdjs.evtTools.common.clamp(Math.round((1 - ratio) * g1 + ratio * g2), 0, 255);
const b = gdjs.evtTools.common.clamp(Math.round((1 - ratio) * b1 + ratio * b2), 0, 255);
console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

parameters.longDescription: Range: 0 to 1, where 0 gives the first color and 1 gives the second color
parameters.name: Ratio

eventsFunctions.description: Converts a RGB string into a hexadecimal string.  Example input: "0;128;255".
eventsFunctions.name: RgbToHex

inlineCode: console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

eventsFunctions.description: Converts a RGB string into a HSL string.  Example input: "0;128;255"".
eventsFunctions.name: RgbToHsl

inlineCode: let v = Math.max(r, g, b), c = v - Math.min(r, g, b), f = (1 - Math.abs(v + v - c - 1));
eventsFunctionContext.returnValue = Math.round(60 * (h < 0 ? h + 6: h)) + ';' + Math.round((f ? c / f: 0) * 100) + ';' + Math.round(((v + v - c) / 2) * 100);

eventsFunctions.description: Converts HSV color values into a RGB string.  Valid input ranges:  H(0 to 360), S(0 to 100), V(0 to 100).
eventsFunctions.name: HsvToRgb

inlineCode: let f = (n , k = (n + h / 60) % 6) => v - v * s * Math.max(Math.min(k, 4 - k, 1), 0);
console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

eventsFunctions.description: Converts a RGB string into a HSV string.  Example input: "0;128;255".
eventsFunctions.name: RgbToHsv

inlineCode: eventsFunctionContext.returnValue = Math.round(60 * (h < 0 ? h + 6: h)) + ';' + Math.round((v && c / v) * 100) + ';' + Math.round(v * 100);
console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

eventsFunctions.description:
Converts a color name into a RGB string.  (Examples: black, gray, white, red, purple, green, yellow, blue)  
Full list of colors: https://www.w3schools.com/colors/colors_names.asp.
eventsFunctions.name: NameToRgb

eventsFunctions.description: Converts HSL color values into a RGB string.  Valid input ranges:  H(0 to 360), S(0 to 100), L(0 to 100).
eventsFunctions.name: HslToRgb

inlineCode: let f = (n, k = (n + h / 30) % 12) => l - a * Math.max(Math.min(k - 3, 9 - k , 1), - 1);
console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

eventsFunctions.description: Converts a color hue (range: 0 to 360) into an RGB color string with 100% saturation and 50% lightness.
eventsFunctions.name: HueToRgb

inlineCode: let f = (n, k = (n + h / 30) % 12) => l - a * Math.max(Math.min(k - 3, 9 - k , 1), - 1);
console.error("Unable to convert a color: ", e);

events.comment: This allows to detect a change of "intial value" on hot reload.
Create the child-object instances.
Create the label that is displayed over the thumb.
Pass the configuration to the behavior.

Children instances must be resized when the parent size change:
- background is resized to take the full dimensions of the parent
- the label is put back at the center of the bar

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

parameters: max(Background.BoundingBoxRight(), max(Label.BoundingBoxRight(), Thumb.BoundingBoxRight())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxLeft(), min(Label.BoundingBoxLeft(), Thumb.BoundingBoxLeft()))
max(Background.BoundingBoxBottom(), max(Label.BoundingBoxBottom(), Thumb.BoundingBoxBottom())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxTop(), min(Label.BoundingBoxTop(), Thumb.BoundingBoxTop()))

events.comment: The parent size is not defined in onCreate so it needs to be done here.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Ahnaf30e
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FPS
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Calculate and display the frames per second (FPS) of the game.
description: Provides an expression to get the current FPS and a text object behavior to display the current FPS.
Frames Per Second (FPS) describes how many times in the last second your game logic was executed.
This includes running behaviors and events, and then rendering the new game state into the game window. The higher the FPS, the more fluid and performant your game looks.
Note: Use the Performance Profiler (inside in the Debugger) for detailed performance information about your game.

events.name: Keep timestamps for every frame inside the lookback period

events.comment: Record how much time has elapsed
Remove any data before the last second from the beginning of the array
Add the current timestamp to the end of the array

parameters.name: accuracy

propertyDescriptors.name: prefix

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (tristan@victrisgames.com)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.fullName: Create multiple copies of an object
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CreateMultipleCopiesOfObject
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Select the object, choose the number of rows and columns, the spacing between rows and columns, the top left starting point, the layer to create the objects on, and the z-order of the objects.
description: This extension can be used to create multiple copies of an object in a wide variety of arrangements, including:
- horizontal row(s)
- vertical column(s)
- a solid rectangle or square
- an evenly spaced grid
- a grid with different spacing between rows and columns
After the objects are created, you can reference their object variables to manage the objects:
* `RowID`:  what horizontal row does this object reside in,
* `ColumnID`:  what vertical column does this object reside in,
* `CreationID`:  starting top-left, and proceeding from left to right, what is the number of the created object,
* `BatchID`:  optional identifier assigned to all objects created
Watch this [tutorial video](https://youtu.be/rlGSlNSRR9w) to see examples of how to use this extension.

eventsFunctions.description:
Create multiple copies of an object.
Select the object, choose the number of rows and columns, the spacing between rows and columns, the top left starting point, the layer to create the objects on, and the z-order of the objects.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Create multiple copies of an object
eventsFunctions.name: CreateMultipleCopiesOfObject
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create _PARAM2_ rows and _PARAM3_ columns of _PARAM1_ objects, with top-left starting position _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_, with _PARAM6_px between rows and _PARAM7_px between columns. Create objects on _PARAM9_ with a Z-value of _PARAM10_. Assign all objects the BatchID of _PARAM8_

events.comment: Temp object is created to record its width and height (which is needed to calculate spacing).
Temp variables to track progress in drawing the grid
Starting at top left, create objects in grid.
If the current row is complete, move to the next row.
If the last row is complete, stop creating new objects.

parameters.description: (Optional) Identifier assigned to all objects created in this batch
parameters.name: BatchID
